channel.title: While loops (Sorry for spamming)
channel.description: First of all, sorry for spamming this board... and second.. how would i add a 1 second interval a while loop without using Thread.Sleep(1000) ???

item.title: While loops (Sorry for spamming)
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Not_a_bot, post:17, topic:445182”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=547868.msg4017351#msg4017351 date=1339736191]

That’s not true… background threading would be the way to go

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/concurrency/worker.html

Like I said

without extreme and unnecessary complications of code

He’s using a button to make a counter decrease. I’m pretty damn sure what you just suggested would be considered redundant for a task like this.
[/quote]

Implying it’s difficult to implement an event callback (which is pretty much the purpose of a background thread)…
I’d say a sluggish/non-responding UI is worse than a “redundant” solution.[/quote]
I’d say a ui is a redundant solution

Read full topic

item.title: While loops (Sorry for spamming)
item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:16, topic:445182”][quote author=Not_a_bot link=topic=547868.msg4017344#msg4017344 date=1339735567]
That’s not true… background threading would be the way to go

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/concurrency/worker.html
[/quote]
Like I said

without extreme and unnecessary complications of code

He’s using a button to make a counter decrease. I’m pretty damn sure what you just suggested would be considered redundant for a task like this.[/quote]

Implying it’s difficult to implement an event callback (which is pretty much the purpose of a background thread)…

[code=java]SwingWorker worker = new SwingWorker<ImageIcon[], Void>() {
@Override
public ImageIcon[] doInBackground() {
final ImageIcon[] innerImgs = new ImageIcon[nimgs];
for (int i = 0; i < nimgs; i++) {
innerImgs[i] = loadImage(i+1);
}
return innerImgs;
}

@Override
public void done() {
    //Remove the "Loading images" label.
    animator.removeAll();
    loopslot = -1;
    try {
        imgs = get();
    } catch (InterruptedException ignore) {}
    catch (java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException e) {
        String why = null;
        Throwable cause = e.getCause();
        if (cause != null) {
            why = cause.getMessage();
        } else {
            why = e.getMessage();
        }
        System.err.println("Error retrieving file: " + why);
    }
}

};
[/code]

I’d say a sluggish/non-responding UI is worse than a “redundant” solution.

Read full topic

item.title: While loops (Sorry for spamming)
item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:14, topic:445182”][quote author=202685 link=topic=547868.msg4017282#msg4017282 date=1339730312]

int counter = 60;
while(counter-- > 0)
     try {
          Thread.sleep(1000);
     } catch (Exception e) {
          e.printStackTrace();
     }

You shouldn’t be using this on a ui because it will freeze the program for 60 seconds… Of course

can u give me something that will work?
[/quote]
There is nothing that will work simultaneously with a ui without extreme and unnecessary complications of code, due to the fact that the ui runs on the same thread as the programming behind it.[/quote]

That’s not true… background threading would be the way to go

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/concurrency/worker.html

Read full topic

item.title: While loops (Sorry for spamming)
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:

[quote=“202685, post:13, topic:445182”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=547868.msg4017278#msg4017278 date=1339730229]

int counter = 60;
while(counter-- > 0)
     try {
          Thread.sleep(1000);
     } catch (Exception e) {
          e.printStackTrace();
     }

You shouldn’t be using this on a ui because it will freeze the program for 60 seconds… Of course
[/quote]

can u give me something that will work?[/quote]
There is nothing that will work simultaneously with a ui without extreme and unnecessary complications of code, due to the fact that the ui runs on the same thread as the programming behind it.

for(;;) {
    if(startTime + 60000L < System.currentTimeMillis()) {
        ...
        break;
    }
}

?

hitting the button brings it to 59 seconds, then hitting it again brings it to 58 ect…

Edited to increase the time although this is really not the way you should be doing this.[/quote]

then it just freezes for 60 seconds
